# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- The nature and purpose of zakat as a religious and economic obligation
- Zakat calculation and the nisab (minimum threshold) requirement
- Categories of zakat recipients and distribution priorities
- Zakat as a tool for poverty reduction and wealth redistribution
- Integration of zakat with government fiscal policy
- Islamic principles of taxation and government revenue sources
- Public spending priorities in Islamic economics
- Macroeconomic effects of zakat-based fiscal systems
- Contemporary implementation and challenges

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Zakat functions as both a religious obligation and an economic mechanism that systematically redistributes wealth from the wealthy to the poor, serving as the foundation of Islamic fiscal policy and providing an alternative to conventional progressive taxation that emphasizes moral obligation alongside legal requirement.
:::
